member.name: T:Ampere.Base.IntRange
member.summary: The range class represents a range of int values. Unlike other implementing classes, IntRange contains an of type int to enumerate through all of the values between the minimum and maximum ranges. By convention, both sides of the range should be inclusive values.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of IntRange, specifying the minimum and maximum values.

member.returns: An instance of the IntRangeEnumerator class

member.summary: Returns an instance of the IntRangeEnumerator that's used to enumerate through the range values of this instance.
member.returns: An instance of the IntRangeEnumerator class

member.name: P:Ampere.Base.IRangify`1.Maximum
member.summary: The maximum value of this range

member.returns: True if the value is inside Range, else false

member.summary: Determines if this Range is inside the bounds of another range.

member.name: T:Ampere.EnumerableUtils.EnumerableUtils
member.summary: A static utility class for .NET

member.name: M:Ampere.EnumerableUtils.EnumerableUtils.Concat``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0}[])
member.summary: Concatenates all IEnumerables which are specified in in the parameter. The concatenation occurs in the order specified in the parameter.
member.typeparam: The enumerable type to be used
member.param: An enumerable of all one dimensional arrays to be concatenated
member.exception: Is thrown if any enumerable, which is a candidate to be concatenated, is null
member.returns: A single enumerable with all of the concatenated elements
member.example: This simple example shows how to call the method.

member.name: M:Ampere.EnumerableUtils.EnumerableUtils.Insert``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0}@,System.Int32,System.Int32,``0[])
member.summary: Inserts the specified element at the specified index in the enumerable (modifying the original enumerable). If element at that position exits, If shifts that element and any subsequent elements to the right, adding one to their indices. The method also allows for inserting more than one element into the enumerable at one time given that they are specified. This Insert method is functionally similar to the Insert method of the List class. for information about the add method of the List class.
member.param: The amount of elements to insert into the enumerable
Optionally, the values to insert into the empty indices of the new enumerable
member.returns: An enumerable of the elements inserted into the enumerable, if any
member.exception: Thrown when the valuesToIns enumerable does not match the amount to insert (if it is greater than 0)
Thrown when the amtToIns or the startIdx is less than 0
member.example: This sample shows how to call the method.

member.name: M:Ampere.EnumerableUtils.EnumerableUtils.IsNullOrEmpty``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Returns whether an IEnumerable is null or empty
member.returns: The truth

member.name: M:Ampere.EnumerableUtils.EnumerableUtils.IsZeroOrOne``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Returns true if the Count of the IEnumerable is zero or one.
member.returns: True if the Count of the IEnumerable is zero or one

member.name: M:Ampere.EnumerableUtils.EnumerableUtils.Range(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Enables python style for-loop for easier readability. This loop begins at the starting value and loops until the end - 1,
member.param: The starting counter for the loop (inclusive)
The ending counter for the loop (exclusive)
member.returns: An IEnumerable representing the current index
member.example: This example shows how to use the method.

member.name: M:Ampere.EnumerableUtils.EnumerableUtils.Shuffle``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0})
member.summary: Cryptographically shuffles an enumerable.
member.typeparam: The element type of the IEnumerable
member.returns: The Shuffled IEnumerable

member.name: M:Ampere.EnumerableUtils.EnumerableUtils.Span(System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Enables python style for-loop for easier readability. This loop begins at the starting value and loops until the end.
member.param: The starting counter for the loop (inclusive)
The ending counter for the loop (inclusive)
member.returns: An IEnumerable representing the current index
member.example: This example shows how to use the method.

member.name: M:Ampere.EnumerableUtils.EnumerableUtils.ToString``1(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{``0},System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Prints a string representation of an enumerable. There are 4 supported lengths for the fmtExp. The default length is 0 and the default behavior depends on the type of the enumerable. If the type is primitive (based on the System.IsPrimitive property) including decimal and string, then it prints the enumerable with a space as a separator between each element. If the enumerable is not primitive, it prints the enumerable with no separator. A fmtExp of length 1 specifies a character to separate each element. The enumerable is printed out, following a default behavior, except with the specified separator rather than the default separator. A fmtExp of length 2 specifies a two characters to mark the left and right outer bounds of the enumerable, A fmtExp of length 3 specifies a character for the left outer bound of the enumerable, followed by a separator character, followed by a character for the right outer bound of the enumerable. If no separator is desired, the "/0+" expression can be specified.The evenlySpacedSeparator parameter specifies whether an even number of spaces should be on both sides of the separator. This parameter ignores Object type enumerables excluding decimal and string.
member.param: The defined expression to be optionally used
Determines whether the spacing between each element should be the same
member.returns: The string representation of the enumerable
member.exception: If arr is null
If the formatting expression length is neither 0 or 3
member.example: This sample shows how to call the method.

member.summary: Replaces all instances of a specific value from a file with another replacement value from a specified line. This overload facilitates the replacement through a Dictionary where the key's is an instance of and the value is an int. This allows for unique replacements to occur in more than one line
member.param: The FileInfo instance to write the value to
A Dictionary of replacement values and line numbers

member.summary: Creates a string from the first character of the string to the first whitespace.
member.exception: Thrown when is null
member.returns: The string retaining the first word

member.name: M:Ampere.StringUtils.StringUtils.ChompAfter(System.String,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a string from the first character of the string to the nth whitespace that is specified.
member.param: The amount of white space to chomp after
member.exception: Thrown when is null
member.returns: The string retaining the chomped word

member.name: M:Ampere.StringUtils.StringUtils.IsValidUri(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if a given string is a valid URI. This checks both HTTP and HTTPS URLs.
member.exception: Thrown when is null
member.returns: True if the URI is valid

member.name: M:Ampere.StringUtils.StringUtils.IsWellFormed(System.String)
member.summary: Checks if a string is well formed. A string is well formed if for every alphabet-recognized character, there is an appropriate closing character. For every inner string, with the exception of characters not defined in the alphabet, in between an opening and closing character, if that string were to be split in half, each half would be a mirror image of each other. A well formed string consists of the default alphabet consists of the following characters: '(',')','{','}','[',']','<','>'.
member.exception: Thrown when is null
member.returns: whether the string is well formed
member.example: The following demonstrates how to use the method.

member.name: M:Ampere.StringUtils.StringUtils.IsWellFormed(System.String,System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary{System.Char,System.Char})
member.summary: Checks if a string is well formed. A string is well formed if for every alphabet-recognized character, there is an appropriate closing character. For every inner string, with the exception of characters not defined in the alphabet, in between an opening and closing character, if that string were to be split in half, each half would be a mirror image of each other. A well formed string consists of the user specified Dictionary of key-value pairs, where the key is the opening character and the value is the closing character.
member.param: the dictionary of key value pairs - where the key represents the opening character and the value represents the closing character
member.exception: Thrown when is null
member.returns: whether the string is well formed
member.example: The following demonstrates how to use the method.

member.summary: Finds the longest common prefix of a group of strings of type
member.param: A group of strings to find the common prefix
A flag whether to ignore case
member.returns: The longest common prefix

member.exception: Thrown when is null
member.returns: The reversed string

member.name: M:Ampere.StringUtils.StringUtils.Shuffle(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Shuffle's characters in a string. The methodology used to generate random indices used for shuffling is cryptographically strong. Due to this nature, there is no guarantee that the return string will be entirely different than the original.
member.param: Determines whether to shuffle spaces or not
member.exception: Thrown when the is null
member.returns: The shuffled string

member.name: M:Ampere.StringUtils.StringUtils.Substring(System.String,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Performs a Substring given a starting and ending index, similar to Java. The operation is performed mathematically as [startIndex, endIndex).
member.returns: A string that is equivalent to the substring that begins at startIndex in this instance, or Empty if startIndex is equal to the length of this instance.

member.name: M:Ampere.StringUtils.StringUtils.IsZeroOrOne(System.String)
member.summary: Returns true if the length of the string is zero or one.
member.returns: True if the length of the string is zero or one
